paragraphs.title: Use Cases
paragraphs.text:
%md 
The figure below illustrates latency and bandwidth/data rate requirements of the various use cases which have been discussed in the context of 5G to date.

[1]:

paragraphs.title: 5G technology requirements
paragraphs.text:
%md 

* 1-10Gbps connections to end points in the field (i.e. not theoretical maximum)
* 1 millisecond end-to-end round trip delay (latency)
* 1000x bandwidth per unit area
* 10-100x number of connected devices
* (Perception of) 99.999% availability
* (Perception of) 100% coverage
* 90% reduction in network energy usage
* Up to ten year battery life for low power, machine-type devices

result.msg:
• 1-10Gbps connections to end points in the field (i.e. not theoretical maximum)
  • 1 millisecond end-to-end round trip delay (latency)
  • 1000x bandwidth per unit area
  • 10-100x number of connected devices
  • (Perception of) 99.999% availability
  • (Perception of) 100% coverage
  • 90% reduction in network energy usage
  • Up to ten year battery life for low power, machine-type devices

paragraphs.title: Difference between 4G and 5G
paragraphs.text:
%md 
From: http://www.androidauthority.com/4g-and-5g-wireless-how-they-are-alike-and-how-they-differ-615709/ 

* Wireless networks till 4G mostly focused on the availability of raw bandwidth, while 5G is aiming on providing pervasive connectivity to lay grounds for fast and resilient access to the Internet users, whether they are on a top of a skyscraper or down under a subway station. Although LTE standard is incorporating a variant called machine type communications (MTC) for the IoT traffic, 5G technologies are being designed from grounds up to support MTC-like devices.

* The 5G networks are not going to be a monolithic network entity and will be built around a combination of technologies: 2G, 3G, LTE, LTE-A, Wi-Fi, M2M, etc. In other words, 5G will be designed to support a variety of applications such as the IoT, connected wearables, augmented reality and immersive gaming.

* The 5G networks will pioneer new architectures like cloud RAN and virtual RAN to facilitate a more centralized network establishment and make the best use of server farms through localized data centers at the network edges.

* 5G will spearhead the use of cognitive radio techniques to allow the infrastructure to automatically decide about the type of channel to be offered, differentiate between mobile and fixed objects, and adapt to conditions at a given time.

result.msg:
From: http://www.androidauthority.com/4g-and-5g-wireless-how-they-are-alike-and-how-they-differ-615709/

  • Wireless networks till 4G mostly focused on the availability of raw bandwidth, while 5G is aiming on providing pervasive connectivity to lay grounds for fast and resilient access to the Internet users, whether they are on a top of a skyscraper or down under a subway station. Although LTE standard is incorporating a variant called machine type communications (MTC) for the IoT traffic, 5G technologies are being designed from grounds up to support MTC-like devices.

  • The 5G networks are not going to be a monolithic network entity and will be built around a combination of technologies: 2G, 3G, LTE, LTE-A, Wi-Fi, M2M, etc. In other words, 5G will be designed to support a variety of applications such as the IoT, connected wearables, augmented reality and immersive gaming.

  • The 5G networks will pioneer new architectures like cloud RAN and virtual RAN to facilitate a more centralized network establishment and make the best use of server farms through localized data centers at the network edges.

  • 5G will spearhead the use of cognitive radio techniques to allow the infrastructure to automatically decide about the type of channel to be offered, differentiate between mobile and fixed objects, and adapt to conditions at a given time.

paragraphs.title: Key Components
paragraphs.text:
%md 
Key technology components of 5G wireless access include access/backhaul integration, device-to-device communication, flexible duplex, flexible spectrum usage, multi-antenna transmission, ultra-lean design, and user/control separation.

paragraphs.title: MegaTrend
paragraphs.text:
%md 
From: 
* Peter Merz, Nokia - 5G Architecture – healthy balance between Evolution and Revolution [video][1], [slide][2]
* Erik Ekudden, Ericsson - The future 5G eco system - Johannesberg Summit 2015 [video][3], slide  
  ![underline factors for network transformation][5]
dimension: digitalization (virtualization: physical -> digital -> data driven), moblization (automation, optization, ML)
    * Core components:
        * Virtualization
        * Network as a Service: slicing
        * Distributed [computing | storage | cloud | intelligent]
        * Software Defined Infrastructure

**pattern**: generalize -> virtualize -> pooling -> customizing
        
* ![network transformation][6]
* ![network architecture][7]

[1]:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zJVZ-BhM3QI
[2]:https://johannesbergsummit.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/6/2014/11/Tuesday_2_Peter-Merz.pdf
[3]:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9NwDEzumkUQ
[5]:https://www.evernote.com/l/AS6SSo9fG69GJ6gv1sLrcAdlGvpsq9OlspA
[6]:http://www.netmanias.com/en/?m=attach&no=13955
[7]:http://www.netmanias.com/en/?m=attach&no=13956
